de.esoco.lib.io

Class XmlWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.io.XmlWriter

  • public class XmlWriter
extends java.lang.Object
    A simple class to write XML files directly to an arbitrary Writer instance. This class performs no buffering by itself, so if necessary a buffered writer implementation should be used for the output. It also performs no XML validation, only some basic structural checks.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      XmlWriter(java.io.Writer rWriter)
      Creates a new instance for a standalone XML file with a version number of 1.0, UTF-8 encoding.

      Creates a new instance with a certain XML declaration at the beginning of the file.

        Creates a new instance for a standalone XML file with a version number of 1.0, UTF-8 encoding.

        Throws:

      • XmlWriter

        public XmlWriter(java.io.Writer rWriter,
                 java.lang.String sVersion,
                 java.lang.String sEncoding,
                 java.lang.Boolean rStandalone)
          throws java.io.IOException
        Creates a new instance with a certain XML declaration at the beginning of the file.
        Parameters:
        rWriter - The writer instance to write the XML to
        sVersion - The XML version used by the file
        sEncoding - The character encoding used for the content or NULL for no value
        rStandalone - TRUE for a file with internal DTD, FALSE for a file with a separate DTD or other external references or NULL for no value
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing the XML header fails

    • Method Detail

      • close

        public void close()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Closes this instance. This flushes any remaining output in the underlying Writer but doesn't close it. The behavior of an instance after closing it is undefined and may cause exceptions.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails or if the internal state of this instance is inconsistent for closing

      • endElement

        public XmlWriter endElement()
                     throws java.io.IOException
        Finishes the structure of an element by writing the corresponding end tag to the output writer. The name of the element is determined from the previous invocation hierarchy of startElement(String) and this method. As an optimization only an empty-element tag will be written if no content has been added to the currently open element.
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails

      • setIndentation

        public final void setIndentation(java.lang.String rIndentation)
        Sets the indentation string. For each indentation level one copy of this string will be added to the output of each line. The default value is a tabulator character.
        Parameters:
        rIndentation - The indentation string or NULL to disable indentation

      • setNamespace

        public void setNamespace(java.lang.String sNamespace)
        Sets the namespace for all subsequent element creations.
        Parameters:
        sNamespace - The namespace

      • startElement

        public XmlWriter startElement(java.lang.String sName)
                       throws java.io.IOException
        Starts the writing of a new element in the XML file. This will open a new starting tag with the given element name and accept the writing of element attributes with writeAttribute(String, String) or of element data with one of the corresponding methods. To finish the element the method endElement() must be invoked.

        Within an element an arbitrary number of child elements can be created by invoking this method as long as all elements are closed correctly with endElement(). The implementation keeps track of the added elements and will throw an exception if the element hierarchy becomes inconsistent.

        Parameters:
        sName - The element name that will appear in the start and end tags
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        See Also:
        Object.toString()

      • writeAttribute

        public XmlWriter writeAttribute(java.lang.String sName,
                                java.lang.String sValue)
                         throws java.io.IOException
        Writes an attribute for the current element. Invocations of this method can only occur directly after an element had been started with the method startElement(String). The writing of attributes is ended by writing element content, child elements, or with endElement().

        Any reserved characters in the attribute value will be replaced with the corresponding XML character entity.

        Parameters:
        sName - The attribute name
        sValue - The attribute value
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails or if no element tag is currently open

      • writeCharacterData

        public XmlWriter writeCharacterData(java.lang.String sData)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Writes a block of unparsed character data as the current element's content. This will insert an XML CDATA block into the output. If the data string contains occurrences of the CDATA termination string ']]>' it will be split into multiple CDATA sections.
        Parameters:
        sData - The string containing the unparsed character data
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails or if no element is currently open

      • writeComment

        public XmlWriter writeComment(java.lang.String sComment)
                       throws java.io.IOException
        Writes a string into an XML comment tag. Comments can be written everywhere in an XML file, either outside of or in elements.
        Parameters:
        sComment - The comment string
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails

      • writeElement

        public XmlWriter writeElement(java.lang.String sName,
                              java.lang.String sText)
                       throws java.io.IOException
        A convenience method that writes an element without attributes and closes it immediately. If the text argument is NULL an empty-element tag will be written.
        Parameters:
        sName - The element name
        sText - The element content or NULL for none
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails

      • writeElement

        public XmlWriter writeElement(java.lang.String sName,
                              java.lang.String sAttribute,
                              java.lang.String sValue,
                              java.lang.String sText)
                       throws java.io.IOException
        A convenience method that writes an element with a single attribute and closes it immediately. If the text argument is NULL an empty-element tag will be written.
        Parameters:
        sName - The element name
        sAttribute - The attribute name
        sValue - The attribute value
        sText - The element content or NULL for none
        Returns:
        This instance for method concatenation
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing to the output writer fails

        Parameters:

        Returns:
